page.title: 11Risley Remand Centre
page.content: Risley Remand Centre became a prison in 1965. During the Second World War it was used as a Royal Navy Base. Risley was chosen as the site for the remand centre, because it occupied a central position between two major cities, Manchester and Liverpool, where a great deal of crime took place. In the Remand Centre there are at least 550 cells with two people per cell. The prisoners get up at about 7.45am each morning, but if they are going to court, they get up at about 6.15am. Most of the prisoners choose to sleep or read during the day. The food they get is porridge or cereal in the morning, bacon and chips in the afternoon and sausage and chips for tea.
